title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement codeofconduct@posit.co. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to glyenzy
text: outlines propose change glyenzy. detailed discussion contributing tidyverse packages, please see development contributing guide code review principles.

title: Contributing to glyenzy
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to glyenzy
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See guide create great issue advice.

title: Contributing to glyenzy
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("glycoverse/glyenzy", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to glyenzy
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to glyenzy
text: Please note glyenzy project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

code: @Manual{,   title = {glyenzy: Deconstruction Glycosylation Biosynthesis},   author = {Bin Fu},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000},   url = {https://glycoverse.github.io/glyenzy/}, }

title: Deconstruction Glycosylation Biosynthesis
text: [!Note] package currently development production use. glyenzy package helps simulate biosynthetic process glycosylation silico. Key features include: identifying specific glycosyltransferase responsible glycosidic bond; reconstructing biosynthetic pathway given glycan; exploring possible transformations two glycan structures via glycosyltransferases glycosidases; predicting glycans can synthesized given substrate structure set enzymes.

title: Apply an Enzyme to a Glycan — apply_enzyme
Apply an Enzyme to a Glycan — apply_enzyme
text: glycans glyrepr::glycan_structure(), character vector glycan structure strings supported glyparse::auto_parse(). enzyme enzyme() gene symbol. return_list NULL (default), return list glyrepr::glycan_structure() glycans length greater 1, single glyrepr::glycan_structure() glycans length 1. Set TRUE always return list. can useful working programmatically unknown input length. Note return_list = FALSE length(glycans) > 1, error thrown.

title: Apply an Enzyme to a Glycan — apply_enzyme
text: glyrepr::glycan_structure() vector, list vectors.

title: Apply an Enzyme to a Glycan — apply_enzyme
text: algorithms enzyme information glyenzy applicable humans, specifically N-glycans O-GalNAc glycans. Results may inaccurate types glycans (e.g., GAGs, glycolipids) glycans species (e.g., plants, insects).

title: Apply an Enzyme to a Glycan — apply_enzyme
text: algorithm takes intentionally inclusive approach, assuming possible isoenzymes capable catalyzing given reaction may involved. Therefore, results interpreted caution. example, humans, detection motif "Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-" return "ST3GAL3" "ST3GAL4". reality, one might active, depending factors tissue specificity.

title: Apply an Enzyme to a Glycan — apply_enzyme
text: function works glycans containing concrete residues (e.g., "Glc", "GalNAc"), glycans generic residues (e.g., "Hex", "HexNAc").

title: Apply an Enzyme to a Glycan — apply_enzyme
text: Subtituents (e.g. sulfation, phosphorylation) supported yet, algorithms might fail glycans subtituents. glycans contains substituents, use glyrepr::remove_substituents() get clean glycans.

title: Apply an Enzyme to a Glycan — apply_enzyme
text: glycan structure incomplete partially degraded, result may misleading.

title: Apply an Enzyme to a Glycan — apply_enzyme
code: library(glyrepr) library(glyparse)  # Use `glycan_structure()` and `enzyme()` glycan <- auto_parse("GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-") apply_enzyme(glycan, enzyme("MGAT3")) #> <glycan_structure[1]> #> [1] GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Man(a1-6)][GlcNAc(b1-4)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> # Unique structures: 1  # Or use characters directly apply_enzyme("GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-", "MGAT3") #> <glycan_structure[1]> #> [1] GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Man(a1-6)][GlcNAc(b1-4)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> # Unique structures: 1  # Vectorized input glycans <- c(   "GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-",   "GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-" ) apply_enzyme(glycans, "MGAT3") #> [[1]] #> <glycan_structure[1]> #> [1] GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Man(a1-6)][GlcNAc(b1-4)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> # Unique structures: 1 #>  #> [[2]] #> <glycan_structure[1]> #> [1] GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)][GlcNAc(b1-4)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> # Unique structures: 1 #>

title: Count Enzyme Steps — count_enzyme_steps
code: library(glyrepr) library(glyparse)  # Use `glycan_structure()` and `enzyme()` glycan <- auto_parse("Neu5Ac(a2-6)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-") count_enzyme_steps(glycan, enzyme("ST6GAL1")) #> [1] 1  # Or use characters directly count_enzyme_steps("Neu5Ac(a2-6)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-", "ST6GAL1") #> [1] 1  # Vectorized input glycans <- c(   "Neu5Ac(a2-6)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-",   "Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-" ) count_enzyme_steps(glycans, "ST6GAL1") #> [1] 1 0

title: Enzymes — enzyme
text: Glycosylation catalyzed two types enzymes: glycosyltransferases (GTs) glycoside hydrolases (GHs). Glycosyltransferases catalyze transfer sugar residue donor acceptor. Glycoside hydrolases catalyze removal sugar residue substrate. glyenzy provides data structure (glyenzy_enzyme) represent enzymes. Use enzyme() gene symbol load predefined enzyme. example, use enzyme("ST3GAL3") load enzyme ST3GAL3. Throughout package, can use enzyme()s enzyme argument, just use gene symbol directly. example, involve("Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-3)GalNAc(a1-", "ST3GAL3") involve("Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-3)GalNAc(a1-", enzyme("ST3GAL3")) equivalent.

title: Enzymes — enzyme
text: symbol gene symbol enzyme.

title: Enzymes — enzyme
text: glyenzy_enzyme object.

title: Enzymes — enzyme
text: enzyme() list following elements: name: name enzyme, usually gene symbol. rules: list glyenzy_enzyme_rule objects. rule list following fields: acceptor: motif enzyme recognizes acceptor_alignment: alignment acceptor rejects: motifs enzyme reject act rejects_alignment: alignment rejects product: product generated enzyme acceptor_idx: node index acceptor enzyme acts . GTs, node new residue attached . GHs, node removed. product_idx: node index product residue product structure. GTs, index newly added residue product. GHs, NULL (new residue added). new_residue: new residue added enzyme. GHs, NULL. new_linkage: linkage new residue. GHs, NULL. type: type enzyme, "GT" glycosyltransferase "GH" glycoside hydrolase. species: species enzyme, e.g. "human" "mouse". can see information printing enzyme object.

title: Enzymes — enzyme
code: library(glyrepr)  enzyme("ST3GAL3") #>  #> ── Enzyme: ST3GAL3 ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> ℹ Type: "GT" (Glycosyltransferase) #> ℹ Species: "human" #>  #> ── Rules (3) ── #>  #> → Rule 1: terminal alignment #> Acceptor: "Gal(b1-3)GlcNAc(b1-" #> Product: "Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-3)GlcNAc(b1-" #> → Rule 2: terminal alignment #> Acceptor: "Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-" #> Product: "Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-" #> → Rule 3: terminal alignment #> Acceptor: "Gal(b1-3)GalNAc(b1-" #> Product: "Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-3)GalNAc(b1-"

what: Find Synthesis Path Between Glycan Structures — find_synthesis_path
title: Find Synthesis Path Between Glycan Structures — find_synthesis_path
text: Find synthesis path one glycan structure another using enzymatic reactions. function uses breadth-first search find shortest path possible paths within given number steps.

title: Find Synthesis Path Between Glycan Structures — find_synthesis_path
code: find_synthesis_path(   from,   to,   enzymes = NULL,   max_steps = 10,   filter = NULL,   return = c("shortest", "all") )

title: Find Synthesis Path Between Glycan Structures — find_synthesis_path
text: glyrepr::glycan_structure() scalar, character string supported glyparse::auto_parse(). starting glycan structure. glyrepr::glycan_structure() scalar, character string supported glyparse::auto_parse(). target glycan structure. enzymes character vector gene symbols, list enzyme() objects. NULL (default), available enzymes used. max_steps Integer, maximum number enzymatic steps search. Default 10. filter Optional function filter generated glycans step. take glyrepr::glycan_structure() vector input return logical vector length. return One "shortest" "". "shortest", returns first shortest path found. "", returns graph containing possible paths within max_steps.

title: Find Synthesis Path Between Glycan Structures — find_synthesis_path
text: igraph::igraph() object representing synthesis path(s). Vertices represent glycan structures name attribute containing IUPAC-condensed strings. Edges represent enzymatic reactions enzyme attribute containing gene symbols step attribute indicating step number.

title: Find Synthesis Path Between Glycan Structures — find_synthesis_path
code: library(glyrepr) library(glyparse)  # Find shortest path from <- "Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-" to <- "Neu5Ac(a2-6)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-" path <- find_synthesis_path(from, to, enzymes = "ST6GAL1", max_steps = 3)  # View the path igraph::as_data_frame(path, what = "edges") #>                  from                              to  enzyme step #> 1 Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- Neu5Ac(a2-6)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- ST6GAL1    1

title: Identify Potentially Involved Enzymes — get_involved_enzymes
code: library(glyrepr) library(glyparse)  # Use `glycan_structure()` glycans <- auto_parse(c(   "GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-",   "GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-" )) get_involved_enzymes(glycans) #> [[1]] #> [1] "MOGS"   "GANAB"  "MAN1B1" "MAN1A1" "MAN1A2" "MAN1C1" "MAN2A1" "MAN2A2" #> [9] "MGAT1"  #>  #> [[2]] #>  [1] "MOGS"   "GANAB"  "MAN1B1" "MAN1A1" "MAN1A2" "MAN1C1" "MAN2A1" "MAN2A2" #>  [9] "MGAT1"  "MGAT2"  #>   # Or use characters directly get_involved_enzymes("GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-") #> [1] "MOGS"   "GANAB"  "MAN1B1" "MAN1A1" "MAN1A2" "MAN1C1" "MAN2A1" "MAN2A2" #> [9] "MGAT1"

text: glycan structure incomplete partially degraded, result may misleading.

title: Determine Whether a Glycan Is Synthesized by a Given Enzyme — is_synthesized_by
text: basic approach straightforward: reaction rule associated enzyme, function checks whether corresponding product motif appears glycan. rule matches, function returns TRUE. N-glycans, additional logic applied handle special cases. Products MGAT1 often trimmed glycoside hydrolases, meaning final glycan product may longer contain original motif. cases, function instead looks specific motif markers determine enzyme involvement.

title: Determine Whether a Glycan Is Synthesized by a Given Enzyme — is_synthesized_by
code: library(glyrepr) library(glyparse)  # Use `glycan_structure()` and `enzyme()` glycan <- auto_parse("Neu5Ac(a2-6)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-") is_synthesized_by(glycan, enzyme("ST6GAL1")) #> [1] TRUE  # Or use characters directly is_synthesized_by("Neu5Ac(a2-6)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-", "ST6GAL1") #> [1] TRUE  # Vectorized input glycans <- c(   "Neu5Ac(a2-6)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-",   "Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-" ) is_synthesized_by(glycans, "ST6GAL1") #> [1]  TRUE FALSE

Default 20. filter Optional function filter generated glycans step. take glyrepr::glycan_structure() vector input return logical vector length. return One "shortest" "". "shortest", returns first shortest path found. "", returns graph containing possible paths within max_steps.

title: Rebuild the Biosynthetic Path of a Glycan — rebuild_biosynthesis
text: N-glycans, starting structure assumed "Glc(3)Man(9)GlcNAc(2)", N-glycan precursor transfered Asn OST. O-glycans, starting structure assumed "GalNAc(a1-".

title: Rebuild the Biosynthetic Path of a Glycan — rebuild_biosynthesis
code: library(glyrepr) library(glyparse)  # Rebuild the biosynthetic pathway of a glycan glycan <- "Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)[Fuc(a1-3)]GlcNAc(b1-3)Gal(b1-3)GalNAc(a1-" path <- rebuild_biosynthesis(glycan, max_steps = 20)  # View the path igraph::as_data_frame(path, what = "edges") #>                                                  from #> 1                                          GalNAc(a1- #> 2                                 Gal(b1-3)GalNAc(a1- #> 3                     GlcNAc(b1-3)Gal(b1-3)GalNAc(a1- #> 4            Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-3)Gal(b1-3)GalNAc(a1- #> 5 Fuc(a1-3)[Gal(b1-4)]GlcNAc(b1-3)Gal(b1-3)GalNAc(a1- #>                                                                to  enzyme step #> 1                                             Gal(b1-3)GalNAc(a1- C1GALT1    1 #> 2                                 GlcNAc(b1-3)Gal(b1-3)GalNAc(a1-  B3GNT3    2 #> 3                        Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-3)Gal(b1-3)GalNAc(a1- B4GALT1    3 #> 4             Fuc(a1-3)[Gal(b1-4)]GlcNAc(b1-3)Gal(b1-3)GalNAc(a1-    FUT3    4 #> 5 Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)[Fuc(a1-3)]GlcNAc(b1-3)Gal(b1-3)GalNAc(a1- ST3GAL3    5

what: Apply Enzymes to Spawn Glycans — spawn_glycans_step
title: Apply Enzymes to Spawn Glycans — spawn_glycans_step
text: function simulates action enzymes glycans. Think like primordial soup put glycans enzymes, let interact generate new glycans. spawn_glycans_step() performs one round enzyme action, spawn_glycans() performs multiple rounds. difference spawn_glycans_step() spawn_glycans(n_steps = 1) latter returns original input glycans well. , vector unique glycan structures returned. number glycans generated spawn_glycans() typically exponential, can quickly become large. Therefore, recommended use small number steps carefully select enzymes. Also, can use filter argument prune results round.

title: Apply Enzymes to Spawn Glycans — spawn_glycans_step
code: spawn_glycans_step(glycans, enzymes)  spawn_glycans(glycans, enzymes, n_steps = 5, filter = NULL)

title: Apply Enzymes to Spawn Glycans — spawn_glycans_step
text: glycans glyrepr::glycan_structure(), character vector glycan structure strings supported glyparse::auto_parse(). enzymes character vector gene symbols, list enzyme() objects. n_steps maximum number rounds perform. actual number rounds may less new glycans can generated. filter function filter generated glycans. single glyrepr::glycan_structure() vector input, return logical vector length. function called results round.

title: Apply Enzymes to Spawn Glycans — spawn_glycans_step
text: glyrepr::glycan_structure() vector unique glycans generated.

title: Apply Enzymes to Spawn Glycans — spawn_glycans_step
text: algorithms enzyme information glyenzy applicable humans, specifically N-glycans O-GalNAc glycans. Results may inaccurate types glycans (e.g., GAGs, glycolipids) glycans species (e.g., plants, insects).

title: Apply Enzymes to Spawn Glycans — spawn_glycans_step
text: algorithm takes intentionally inclusive approach, assuming possible isoenzymes capable catalyzing given reaction may involved. Therefore, results interpreted caution. example, humans, detection motif "Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-" return "ST3GAL3" "ST3GAL4". reality, one might active, depending factors tissue specificity.

title: Apply Enzymes to Spawn Glycans — spawn_glycans_step
text: function works glycans containing concrete residues (e.g., "Glc", "GalNAc"), glycans generic residues (e.g., "Hex", "HexNAc").

title: Apply Enzymes to Spawn Glycans — spawn_glycans_step
text: Subtituents (e.g. sulfation, phosphorylation) supported yet, algorithms might fail glycans subtituents. glycans contains substituents, use glyrepr::remove_substituents() get clean glycans.

title: Apply Enzymes to Spawn Glycans — spawn_glycans_step
text: glycan structure incomplete partially degraded, result may misleading.

title: Apply Enzymes to Spawn Glycans — spawn_glycans_step
code: # Use `spawn_glycans_step()` to build glycans step by step glycan <- "GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-" glycan |>   spawn_glycans_step("MGAT2") |>   spawn_glycans_step("B4GALT1") |>   spawn_glycans_step("ST3GAL3") #> <glycan_structure[2]> #> [1] Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [2] Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> # Unique structures: 2  # Use `spawn_glycans()` to simulate a primordial soup glycans <- c(   "GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-",   "GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-" ) enzymes <- c("B4GALT1", "ST3GAL3") spawn_glycans(glycans, enzymes, n_steps = 5) #> <glycan_structure[12]> #> [1] GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [2] GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [3] Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [4] Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [5] Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [6] Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [7] Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [8] Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [9] Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [10] Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)[Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> ... (2 more not shown) #> # Unique structures: 12  # Use `filter` to prune the results after each round # Here we keep only glycans that are synthesized by MGAT2 spawn_glycans(glycans, enzymes, n_steps = 5, filter = ~ is_synthesized_by(.x, "MGAT2")) #> <glycan_structure[9]> #> [1] GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [2] Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [3] Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [4] Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [5] Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [6] Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [7] Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)[Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [8] Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [9] Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> # Unique structures: 9
